drupalNodeEvent.title: Liu Xiang baojuan: A Case Study in Tradition and Creativity in Qing Popular Religious Literature

field_speakers.processed: Katherine Alexander (Asian Languages & Civilizations, University of Colorado)

field_organizers.processed: East Asia Center at UC Santa Barbara

field_description.processed: Liu Xiang baojuan was perhaps the most widely reprinted precious scroll of the late Qing. In this talk, I propose a critical reassessment of this understudied text by focusing on features of its narrative style and structure that enhanced both its promotion of lay Buddhist practices and its entertainment value. Between scenes of moralistic instruction come dramatic instances of shocking violence, ironic humor, and romantic intimacy. In doing so, I depart from earlier treatments of the text as a repository of premodern Chinese female misery. Instead of reading Liu Xiang as a story that reflected the plight of female audiences, can we read it as a story that brought its Qing audiences pleasure, both in their piety and their need for a good tale?
